If you’re an avid Aldi shopper (or hope to be one), then you’ll want to listen up. The grocer plans to open more locations in 2025 than it ever has in one calendar year in its five decades of operating in the United States. If you don’t have a store near you, that could all change in a few months.

A few days ago, Aldi announced plans to open over 225 new stores in 2025. So, if your nearby location always has long lines — or if you don’t have one close to you — this expansion could change and improve your shopping trips.

“This is the most stores Aldi will open in one year in its nearly 50-year U.S. history as more shoppers than ever look to save up to 36% on an average shopping trip,” the grocery chain said in a press release. This plan to increase the number of locations in the U.S. is part of the company’s five-year national growth strategy, which aims to open nearly 800 stores nationwide by 2028.

In 2025, Aldi locations will open in new buildings and select converted Winn-Dixie and Harveys Supermarket locations the brand added to its portfolio when it acquired Southeastern Grocers, the parent company of Winn-Dixie and Harveys. While the company hasn’t revealed the exact addresses yet, its press release notes that nearly 220 Southeastern Grocers stores — which have the potential to span Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia, and Puerto Rico — will be transformed into Aldi locations through 2027. 

“Aldi continues to see more shoppers come through our doors as they experience our quicker, easier, and more affordable shopping experience firsthand,” Jason Hart, CEO of Aldi, said in a press release. “With our expansion across the country, Aldi is earning the trust of more shoppers in more communities than ever before, bringing us closer to becoming America’s first stop for groceries,” Hart added.

In the future, Aldi plans to expand its presence in the Northeast, Midwest, West, Southern California, and Arizona and to enter new communities like Las Vegas. So if you’ve been waiting for an Aldi to open up in your community, 2025 might be your year. Just don’t forget your cart quarter!
